div.head: Structure of an LDLT Edition
div.p: This section describes the basic structure of the file that contains an edition for the Digital Latin Library's Library of Digital Latin Texts (LDLT). The structure of an LDLT edition resembles the structure of a traditional printed critical edition:

list.head: Parts of an LDLT Edition
list.item: Publication Details
Front Matter
Critical Text (including apparatus)
Indices

div.p: Since every text is unique, not every LDLT edition will have all of these sections. The nature of the text and the editor's judgment will determine the contents of an edition. The purpose of this section is to define the parts of an LDLT edition and provide guidelines for representing them in XML.
These guidelines are based on the standard set by the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), with modification and customization to accommodate the special characteristics of Latin texts.
The following is an example of the general overall structure of an XML file for an LDLT edition:

availability.license: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

div.head: Preface
div.p: General introductory remarks about the edition.

div.head: List of Scholars Referred to By Name
Publication Details
div.p: A traditional critical edition in print has a title page announcing the title of the work, its author, the editor(s), and details of publication. In an LDLT edition, these details are presented as structured data within a TEI header (teiHeader). For example:

availability.license: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

div.p: Since a critical edition is often based upon many sources (e.g., manuscripts, previous editions, commentaries, etc.), the teiHeader for an LDLT edition does not hew strictly to the TEI guidelines for sourceDesc. The sources for an LDLT edition are documented and described in the edition's front matter.
Just as an editor is not expected to create the title page and document the publication information, this section of an LDLT is the responsibility of the DLL staff.

div.head: Front Matter
div.p: The front contains divisions and subdivisions (using div) corresponding to the preface, bibliography, and conspectus for the edition.

The preface lays out (in prose, using p) the argument for the edition. It also describes the textual tradition and the major sources for it, which is why it is recommended to compile the bibliography first, to take advantage of the ability to link to individual entries in the bibliography, so that users will be able to have the information available as they read.

The elements available in all TEI documents are available for use in the preface. For example, an editor might want to make a table comparing the readings of manuscript families. In that case, the editor would use table and its related elements (see the TEI guidelines for table for more information).

div.head: Bibliography
div.p: The bibliography presents opportunities for leveraging the digital nature of an LDLT edition. For this reason, every item in the bibliography is encoded as structured data (contained in msDesc or biblStruct), so that the bibliography itself can become a useful tool for finding and using resources, especially those that are available online.

The bibliography is all the more useful as a tool if it is created and made available via Zotero, an open, online resource for building and managing bibliographies. In addition to providing an interface for compiling and managing a bibliography, Zotero can also export bibliographies in a TEI XML format that requires little to no modification for inclusion in an LDLT edition. Users can copy and paste Zotero information directly into an LDLT edition file. It is highly recommended that all LDLT editions have a corresponding Zotero repository for their bibliography.

Unfortunately, Zotero does not currently provide a format for describing and cataloging manuscripts, so that information must be entered manually. For that reason, and for the sake of completeness, the following sections provide information for encoding items in the bibliography, with examples.

div.head: Structure of the Bibliography
div.p: The bibliography should be organized according to the following structure:

list.head: Structure of the Bibliography for an LDLT Edition
list.item: Manuscripts (xml:id="bibliography-manuscripts")

Editions
Early Editions (xml:id="bibliography-editions-witnesses"
Modern Editions (xml:id="bibliography-editions-sources")
Secondary Sources (xml:id="bibliography-secondary-sources")

div.p: Additionally, there should be a list of the names of individual scholars (xml:id="bibliography-scholars") referred to by name in the apparatus, if they are not listed elsewhere in the bibliography (e.g., as the editor of an edition or author of an article). It is common, for example, to refer to a scholar whose unpublished notes appear in a commentary or who has corresponded with the editor. For ease of reference, these sources should be listed with information about where the information can be verified.

div.head: Human- and Machine-Readable Sigla, Symbols, and Abbreviations
div.p: Printed editions have long used a system of references for manuscripts and other materials in the bibliography. For example, single letters, or sigla, stand for manuscripts, and the last names of scholars stand for editions, commentaries, or other works of scholarship. Centuries of use have demontrated that this system of sigla and other symbols and abbreviations is an efficient, effective, and economical way of presenting the complex information contained in critical editions. Although its development was motivated by the constraints of the printed page, its virtues for representing data commend it for other media, too. But just as the printed page has limits, so too does the digital file, so the traditional system requires an update to make it available in a digital context.

Given some guidance and experience, people can learn how to navigate the system of letters, numbers, symbols, and other typographical conventions for referring to the sources of a crticial edition. If one edition uses superscript numerals to indicate the hands that wrote in a manuscript, but another uses superscript numerals to signify the number of a manuscript in a collection, a human reader can adjust to the difference in meaning without much effort. In contrast, machines need clear instructions and a reliable set of rules for reading a digital file. A human might see N² and correctly interpret it within a particular edition as meaning "text written by the second person in a succession of people who wrote in the manuscript known as codex Neapolitanus V A 8." Without explicit instructions, a machine will interpret the same information as simply the letter "N" with a superscript numeral 2 next to it. Indeed, a less experienced human reader might reach the same conclusion as the machine.

Since the audience for LDLT editions includes an entirely new class of reader (i.e., machines), it stands to reason that the reference system should be adapted to accommodate the needs of the expanded readership. For this reason, LDLT editions encode sigla and other aspects of the traditional reference system in two ways: a machine-readable version (using xml:id) and a human-readable version (using label, with special instructions for rendering typographical conventions such as superscript and subscript notation). In some cases, the values for both will be the same, but the strict rules of the XML specification for xml:id do not allow for the traditional system of combining letters with superscript and/or subscript numerals. Nevertheless, the values of xml:id and label should be similar, if not identical, to each other, and they should be meaningful. Editors should follow the conventions in previous editions of the same text, changing a siglum only if it is important to the edition's argument to do so. If the text has never been edited, the editor should choose sigla according to the principles outlined by West (74–75). In brief, use sigla that have mnemonic value (e.g., "V" for "Vaticanus" or "P" for "Parisinus").
Because the needs of editors will vary from edition to edition, the LDLT does not have strict rules for representing manuscript hands or similar information. Rather, we offer these suggestions:

row.cell: Multiple books or articles by the same scholar

div.p: In short, every entry, regardless of type, in the bibliography of an LDLT edition must have values for both xml:id and label. Otherwise, the edition will not be able to make full use of the digital format. Morever, if an entry lacks a label, it will not be available for a print version of the edition, should one be produced.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: The description of manuscripts is a discipline unto itself, with long-established conventions for capturing all of the details about not only a manuscript's contents, but also its dimensions, provenance, material, and other physical details. It is customary for critical editions to provide a brief prose description of the major manuscripts used for establishing the text, usually only enough to identify where the manuscript may be found for consultation, but sometimes including information about its provenance and other details relevant to the edition (e.g., manuscript hands).

The prose format for describing manuscripts is a predictable and efficient way of conveying this information to human readers, but it is not useful for making the information available to machines for processing. That is why the TEI guidelines have an entire module for making manuscript descriptions available as structured data for machine-readability (10 Manuscript Description). But just as editors often eschew the finer points of manuscript description in prose, so too is it acceptable to omit many of the elements of the TEI's module.

LDLT editions must include both structured data and prose descriptions of manuscripts referred to in the apparatus criticus or elsewhere. It is possible to combine the two types of description. Guidelines for structured data, prose, and a combination of the two appear below. Above all, the point is to make the information available to both human and machine readers, so it is up to individual editors to decide which method is most appropriate.

Whatever the method, editors should use their best judgment regarding the amount of information that will be relevant to those seeking to understand the place of a manuscript in the tradition. The following guidelines present the minimum requirements for both prose and structured data descriptions of manuscripts used in LDLT editions.

div.head: Structured Data
div.p: The TEI's module for manuscript description offers a model for presenting nearly every imaginable detail about a manuscript as structured data. Editors may wish to use more of the features of the module than are described here, but the following are essential for making use of the functionality of the LDLT viewer.

listWit (list of witnesses) contains the descriptions of manuscript witnesses for the edition. Separate listWit elements may be used to distinguish families of manuscripts. If it is desirable to use a siglum to refer to the consensus of manuscripts in that family, listWit must have xml:id and label with values corresponding to that siglum.

witness (witness) groups the information about a single manuscript, including the name used to refer to the manuscript in the edition (e.g., Codex Neapolitanus V A 8). Its xml:id is the unique machine-readable identifier to be used when referring to the manuscript's data (e.g., in the wit of a rdg in the apparatus criticus).
label contains the human-readable siglum that should be displayed on screen or printed.
msDesc (manuscript description) groups the elements that compose the description of the manuscript:

list.head: Required Elements in msDesc
list.item: msIdentifier (manuscript identifier) groups information about the location and inventory number of the manuscript.
settlement contains the common English name of the place (e.g., Florence, not Firenze) where the manuscript is located.
institution contains the name of the institution that houses the manuscript. Use the original name of the institution (e.g., Biblioteca Ambrosiana), not an English translation.
repository contains the name of the collection to which the manuscript belongs. Use the original name or common abbreviation of the repository (e.g., Acquisti e Doni or Acq. e Doni).
idno (identifier) contains the catalog or inventory information for the manuscript.
altIdentifier (alternative identifier) contains other information (i.e., in addition to the idno) used to identify the manuscript.
phsyDesc (physical description) groups information about the manuscript.
objectDesc (object description) contains supportDesc (support description). It may have form to identify whether the manuscript is a codex, a set of unbound leaves, or other form.
supportDesc (support description) is an empty element that identifies (in material) the material upon which the manuscript's text is written (e.g., "parchment").
handDesc (hand description) groups information about the distinct hands that wrote in the manuscript. Use hands with the value of the number of hands detectable in the manuscript.

handNote contains information about a hand that wrote in the manuscript. Each handNote has an xml:id with a unique identifier (based on the xml:id of the manuscript) and a label with a human-readable version of the value of the hand's xml:id (see above for more on sigla).
history groups information about the date of the manuscript.

origin encloses origDate, which contains the roman numeral for the century in which the manuscript was written, or the arabic numeral for the year, if known. If century is used, include notBefore and notAfter with appropriate values. If year is used, it should be enclosed by date.

div.head: Prose Description
div.p: In general, nothing prohibits editors of a LDLT edition from describing every last detail of the manuscripts they have used to establish the text, but if the manuscript has been fully described to the editor's satisfaction elsewhere, that work should be cited instead. What to describe depends to a great degree on the nature of the text, the relevance of the information, and the needs of the edition's readership. At the very least, the prose description of a manuscript must include sufficient information for finding the physical object. It must also include the siglum used to identify it in the present edition, and a discussion of any deviation from previous editions in this regard. A date, whether general or specific, is also required. If images of the manuscript are available on the internet, the URL and date of access should be included.

list.head: Required Elements of a Prose Description of a Manuscript
list.item: Siglum
Settlement (i.e., city or town)
Institution (i.e., library or museum), with the name of the collection within the institution, if available
Identification number
Date (general or specific)
URL (if available) and date of access

div.p: In keeping with established practice, commonly used English names of towns should be used (e.g., Florence, not Firenze), but the original name should be used for institutions and repositories (e.g., Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Ottobonianus). Commonly used abbreviations may be used, especially in cases of well known collections or libraries.
Prose descriptions of manuscripts should be in a section of the preface. Each description should be in its own paragraph.
p (paragraph) contains the prose description of one manuscript. It should have corresp pointing to the xml:id of the structured data description of the manuscript in the bibliography.

ref (reference) defines a reference to the URL of digital images of the manuscript or to the structured data version of the manuscript description in the bibliography of the edition (e.g., for references to the manuscript hands).
hi (highlighted) with rend="bold" distinguishes the manuscript's siglum from the rest of the text.
quote contains any text that is repeated from another source. If in Latin, xml:lang="la" should be used.
bibl (bibliographic citation) contains information about works contained in the manuscript.
title within bibl contains the title of a work contained in the manuscript.
Example of the minimum required prose description:

egXML.p: P: Vatican City, BAV, Pal. lat. 1643. XV. URL: http://digi.vatlib.it/view/MSS_Pal.lat.1643 (accessed 2016-08-04).

div.p: Example of a fuller manuscript description, with discussion of manuscript hands:

egXML.p: N: Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale di Napoli, V.A.8, formerly 380, parchment, 261 X 160 mm. It was written at about the beginning of the fifteenth century. It consists of 116 leaves, of which 1–36ʳ contain Cato's De Agricultura; 20–101ʳ, Varro's De Re Rustica; 101ʳ–115ᵛ, the Bucolica of Calpurnius and Nemesianus. The remaining leaves are blank. Each page has thirty-eight verses. With respect to correcting hands, two in particular stand out. The first belongs to the original copyist. The manuscript was corrected again around the same time, but here and there the second hand cannot easily be distinguished from the first. A third hand's emendations can be discerned in only a few places. The individual poems lack titles, but they are separated from each other by brief spaces. The following subscription appears at the end of the whole work: Aureliani Nemesiani Cartag̅ bucol’ explicit: Deo gratias amen. Finally, another more recent hand, as Bursian and Schenkl recognized, wrote Calpurnii eclogae and Nemesiani eclogae.

div.p: For more information on manuscript description, including bibliography and examples, see Raymond Clemens and Timothy Graham, Introduction to Manuscript Studies (Ithaca, Cornell University Press), 2007.

div.head: Combined Structured Data and Prose Description
div.p: To avoid duplication of effort, it is possible to include the prose version in the structured data version of the manuscript description. In this option, the TEI's module for manuscript description will determine the pattern and structure of the description, and certain information will be encoded according to the module's guidelines.

msContents.p: 1–36ʳ contain Cato's De Agricultura; 20–101ʳ, Varro's De Re Rustica; 101ʳ–115ᵛ, the Bucolica of Calpurnius and Nemesianus. The individual poems lack titles, but they are separated from each other by brief spaces. The following subscription appears at the end of the whole work: Aureliani Nemesiani Cartag̅ bucol’ explicit: Deo gratias amen. Finally, another more recent hand, as Bursian and Schenkl recognized, wrote Calpurnii eclogae and Nemesiani eclogae. The remaining leaves are blank.

physDesc.p: Parchment: 261 X 160 mm.: 116 leaves: 38 verses per page.

handDesc.p: With respect to correcting hands, two in particular stand out.
handDesc.handNote: N1 belongs to the original copyist.

handNote.label: N2: The manuscript was corrected again around the same time, but here and there the second hand cannot easily be distinguished from the first.

handDesc.handNote: N3: a third hand's emendations can be discerned in only a few places.

div.head: Common Elements for All Entries
div.p: All entries for items other than manuscripts will have certain common elements.
Entries should be contained in biblStruct with xml:id and label as described above. Entries should also be classified with type and encoded according to the guidelines and examples below.
Publication information for all types of entries should be handled with these elements:
imprint groups information pertaining to the publication of the edition

pubPlace (place of publication) contains the name of the place where the edition was published, as it appears on the title page (e.g., Lipsiae instead of Leipzig). If the place is unknown, the value should be "s.l." (sine loco).
publisher contains the name of the publisher, as it appears on the title page. If the publisher's name is unknown, the value should be "s.n." (sine nomine)
date contains the date in arabic numerals (e.g., 1504, not MDIV or CIↃIↃIV). If the date is unknown, the value should be "s.d." (sine die).
note with type="url" contains the URL for an online copy of the edition, if available.

div.head: Editions
div.p: Previous editions must be classified in one of two categories: early editions based on a single manuscript and modern critical editions based on more than one source. This will have ramifications for how the editions are handled in the apparatus criticus (see below, Apparatus Criticus). This distinction should be preserved in the bibliography with the use of two listBibl lists, with type "witness" and "source", respectively. Editors may provide a head for each of the two lists (e.g., "Ancient Editions" and "Modern Editions"), if they so desire. The structure of the individual entries should be the same in both lists.
The individual entries in each listBibl should have type="book".

biblStruct (structured bibliographic citation) is the top-level element for each edition. It should have type of "book". The values for xml:id and label should be based on the surname of the editor (e.g., Burm1731 and Burm. 1731, respectively for an edition by Burman pubished in 1731). Additionally, if the bibliography has been generated by Zotero, each entry should have corresp with the URL for the entry in the online Zotero bibliography.
monogr (monographic level) groups bibliographic elements describing an edition.

title contains a form of the title of the edition. Because of the great variation in titles for editions, ranging from none at all to heavily ornamented, and because it can be assumed that the editions listed in this section contain the work in question, title may be shortened or abbreviated at the discretion of the editor.

editor contains information identifying the editor of the edition, with xml:id if the editor will be mentioned by name in the apparatus criticus or elsewhere in the edition. If the edition has more than one editor, use one editor element for each editor.
name contains the value "Anonymous" in cases where the name of the editor is not known.
forename contains the first and middle names, or initials, of an editor in cases where that information is known.
surname contains the last name of an editor, in cases where that information is known.
addname (additional name) contains a nickname or a Latin name by which an editor might be known (e.g., "Ascensius").
Publication information is handled according to the guidelines in the section above on publication.

If there is a digital copy of the work available, use two note elements: one with type="accessed" to indicate the date when the resource was retrieved, and one with type="url" and target with the value of the URL to provide the address where the resource was found.

monogr.title: Buccolica, cum adnotatione Ascensiana, jam diligentius recognita

imprint.pubPlace: Parrhisiis in vico Maturinorum et regione domus Cluniacensis

div.p: These will be rendered on screen and in print as follows:

s = Josse Badius ("Ascensius"). Buccolica, cum adnotatione Ascensiana, jam diligentius recognita. Parrhisiis in vico Maturinorum et regione domus Cluniacensis: a M. Durando Gerlerio. 1503. URL: http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k841539v (accessed 2016-05-26T16:32:29Z).

Burm. 1731 = Pieter Burman. Poetae Latini Minores …. Leidae: Conrad Wishoff et Daniel Goedval. 1731. URL: https://books.google.com/books?id=uKZAAAAAcAAJ&pg=PP9#v=onepage&q&f=false (accessed 2016-05-26T16:32:29Z).

div.head: Books Other than Editions
div.p: The bibliographical information for monographs, commentaries, and other books that are not editions should be handled using these elements and attributes:

biblStruct (structured bibliographic citation) is the top-level element for each book. It should have type of "book". The values for xml:id and label should be based on the surname of the author. Additionally, if the bibliography has been generated by Zotero, each entry should have corresp with the URL for the entry in the online Zotero bibliography.
monogr (monographic level) groups bibliographic elements describing a book.
title with level="m" (monographic) contains the full title of the book.

author contains information identifying the author of the book, with xml:id if the author will be mentioned by name in the apparatus criticus or elsewhere in the edition. If the book has more than one author, use one author element for each author.
name contains the value "Anonymous" in cases where the name of the author is not known.
forename contains the first and middle names (middle name optional), or initials, of an author in cases where that information is known.
surname contains the last name of an author, in cases where that information is known.
addname (additional name) contains a nickname or Latin form of a name, if one is commonly used.
Publication information is handled according to the guidelines in the section above on publication.

If there is a digital copy of the work available, use two note elements: one with type="accessed" to indicate the date when the resource was retrieved, and one with type="url" and target with the value of the URL to provide the address where the resource was found.
This will be rendered on screen and in print as follows:
Wilamowitz = Wilamowitz-Moellendorff, Ulrich von. Coniectanea. Göttingen: Dieterich'sche Druckerei. 1884. URL: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nnc2.ark:/13960/t8jd66k2f (accessed 2016-05-26T16:32:29Z).

div.head: Articles
div.p: Bibliographic details for articles published in journals should be encoded using the following elements and attributes:

biblStruct (structured bibliographic citation) is the top-level element for each article. It should have type of "journalArticle" (note case). The values for xml:id and label should be based on the surname of the author. Additionally, if the bibliography has been generated by Zotero, each entry should have corresp with the URL for the entry in the online Zotero bibliography.
analytic (analytic level) groups items relating to an article published within a journal volume.

list.head: Items Contained By analytic
list.item: title with level="a" contains the title of the article.

author contains information identifying the author of the book, with xml:id if the author will be mentioned by name in the apparatus criticus or elsewhere in the edition.. If the book has more than one author, use one author element for each author.
forename contains the first and middle names (middle name optional), or initials, of an author in cases where that information is known.
surname contains the last name of an author, in cases where that information is known.

div.p: monogr (monographic level) groups bibliographic elements describing the journal.

list.head: Items Contained by mongr
list.item: title with level="j" contains the title of the journal.
imprint groups several biblScope elements defining publication information. All numbers should be arabic numerals.

biblScope (scope of bibliographic reference) is used with unit to indicate details of publication:
unit="volume" contains the volume number of the journal in which the article has been published
unit="issue" contains the number of the issue within the volume
unit="page" contains the inclusive pages where the article may be found
date contains the year of publication

item.p: If there is a digital copy of the work available, use two note elements: one with type="accessed" to indicate the date when the resource was retrieved, and one with type="url" and target with the value of the URL to provide the address where the resource was found.

div.p: Note that a review of an edition or other work should be handled in the same way as a journal article, with the exception of the title in analytic, which should begin with the words "Review of" followed by the title of the work being reviewed.

analytic.title: "Calpurnii et Nemesiani Bucolica recensuit Henricus Schenkl, Lipsiae, G. Freytag, Pragae, F. Tempsky, 1885"

div.p: The two examples will be rendered on screen or in print as follows:
Postgate = Postgate, John Percival, "Some Suggestions on Calpurnius Siculus." The Classical Review 15.4 (1901): 213–214. URL: http://www.jstor.org/stable/694806, accessed 2016-05-26T16:32:29Z.

L. Mueller = Müller, Lucian, "Calpurnii et Nemesiani Bucolica recensuit Henricus Schenkl, Lipsiae, G. Freytag, Pragae, F. Tempsky, 1885." Berliner philologische Wochenschrift 5 (1885): 1065–1073. URL: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uiug.30112023962282, accessed accessed 2016-05-26T16:32:29Z.

div.head: List of Scholars
div.p: Occasionally it is necessary to refer to a scholar whose unpublished work has been quoted or paraphrased elsewhere. For example, editors often cite Nicolaas Heinsius' unpublished conjectures, found in books in his own library. But "Heins." does not help a reader find more information. That is why the bibliography of an LDLT edition includes a list of scholars mentioned by name in the edition, with information about where to find their remarks, if they are available.
listPerson with xml:id="bibliography-scholars" groups the information identifying the scholars.
person with xml:id and n as described above.

persName (personal name) groups the information about the scholar's name. Note that it is helpful, but not required, to use ref with the Virtual International Authorify File (VIAF) permalink for that person.
forename contains the scholar's first and middle names (middle name optional), or initials, of the scholar. A separate forename should be used for the first and middle names.
surname contains the scholar's last name.
addname (additional name) contains an additional or alternate name by which a scholar is known.
ref (reference) contains a reference to the entry in the bibliography that has citations of the scholar. target with the xml:id of the entry will cause the reference to point to that entry.
note contains further information about the nature of the citation (e.g., "personal correspondence with editor").

person.note: Unpublished opinions cited in Schenkl's editions.

div.head: Edition Text
div.p: The edition text corresponds to the text printed "above the line" of the critical apparatus in a traditional edition. It is composed of "accepted readings," that is, text judged by the editor to be authentic, accurate, or authoritative.

There may be more than one authoritative version of a text, depending on the text and depending on the approach adopted by the editor. Authors sometimes edit and revise their work over time. Scribes often record the version of the text that makes sense in their context. Scholars and other readers offer conjectures for problematic passages. But an editor must make decisions about the text an edition presents to readers. Combined, those decision constitute the editor's argument about the text, and they are on display in the official edition text in its initial state.

Since the online version of an LDLT allows readers to swap readings from the critical apparatus into the main text, it is possible to encounter many versions of the text in one viewing of it, but the official edition text is the starting point for those interactions.
This section establishes guidelines for encoding the information typically found in the main text of a critical edition.

div.head: Prose
div.p: The aim of this section is to provide guidance for marking up the structure of prose texts, using the generic model of book, chapter, and paragraph for the main components of a work.

div (division) marks first-order (e.g., book) and second-order (e.g., chapter) sections of the prose text. type and subtype should be used to describe the parts of the text; n must be used with second-order divisions to indicate their order in the sequence of the work:

For an LDLT edition, the top-level div has the type "edition"; this division contains the entire text of the edition. The next div will normally have the type "textpart" with subtype "book" and n "1" to indicate that this is the first book. If a different division scheme is required, editors should consult the DLL staff.
milestone can be used to mark the sections of a canonical edition, if the current edition uses a different scheme.
p (paragraph) contains the text of a chapter or other basic section in a prose work. n must be used to reflect the numbering scheme of the edition.
seg (segment) contains a segment of a paragraph (e.g., a sentence or a more general "section"). If seg is used, n must be used to reflect the numbering scheme of the edition.

p.seg: Gallia est omnis divisa in partes tres, quarum unam incolunt Belgae, aliam Aquitani, tertiam qui ipsorum lingua Celtae, nostra Galli appellantur.
Hi omnes lingua, institutis, legibus inter se differunt. Gallos ab Aquitanis Garumna flumen, a Belgis Matrona et Sequana dividit.

Horum omnium fortissimi sunt Belgae, propterea quod a cultu atque humanitate provinciae longissime absunt, minimeque ad eos mercatores saepe commeant atque ea quae ad effeminandos animos pertinent important, proximique sunt Germanis, qui trans Rhenum incolunt, quibuscum continenter bellum gerunt.
Qua de causa Helvetii quoque reliquos Gallos virtute praecedunt, quod fere cotidianis proeliis cum Germanis contendunt, cum aut suis finibus eos prohibent aut ipsi in eorum finibus bellum gerunt.

Eorum una, pars, quam Gallos obtinere dictum est, initium capit a flumine Rhodano, continetur Garumna flumine, Oceano, finibus Belgarum, attingit etiam ab Sequanis et Helvetiis flumen Rhenum, vergit ad septentriones.
Belgae ab extremis Galliae finibus oriuntur, pertinent ad inferiorem partem fluminis Rheni, spectant in septentrionem et orientem solem.
Aquitania a Garumna flumine ad Pyrenaeos montes et eam partem Oceani quae est ad Hispaniam pertinet; spectat inter occasum solis et septentriones.

div.p: In a traditional critical edition, numbers are printed in the margin and/or in the text itself. It is often unclear whether the numbers are meant to mark syntactic units, reflect the numbering of pages or sections in a canonical edition, or something else. When the numbers are printed in the text, it can be unclear

Note that the TEI Guidelines define the paragraph as the fundamental organizational unit for all prose texts. The unique characteristics of some texts may require a different approach. In those cases, editors should work with DLL staff to identify the best way to encode the text in question.

div.head: Verse
div.p: The verse module of the TEI Guidelines offers many possibilities for marking up various aspects of prosody, but the LDLT is primarily concerned with the core tags for encoding the structure of verse texts. This does not mean that editors and others should avoid using the verse module. It means only that the LDLT does not provide functionality for that level of detail.
div1 (level-1 text division) groups the parts of a book of verse, with type="book" and n with the number of the book.
div2 (level-2 text division) groups the parts of a single poem (e.g., stanzas or lines), with type="poem", n with the number of the poem in the book, and met with the name of the meter.
lg (line group) groups one or more verse lines that form a stanza or a couplet, with type and "stanza" or "couplet".
l (line) contains the text of a single line of verse, with n and the number of the line.

lg.l: bellique causas et vitia et modos

div.head: Dialogue
div.p: Texts that feature interlocutors (e.g., drama, dialogue) should be encoded using sp and speaker.
sp (speech) groups elements related to a person or character's speech.
who is used with sp to identify the speaker.
speaker contains a human-readable label identifying the person or character speaking the text.
These features can be used in verse and prose texts:

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nondum Solis equos declinis mitigat aestas,
quamvis et madidis incumbant prela racemis
et spument rauco ferventia musta susurro.
cernis ut ecce pater quas tradidit, Ornyte, vaccae
molle sub hirsuta latus explicuere genista?
nos quoque vicinis cur non succedimus umbris?
torrida cur solo defendimus ora galero?

sp.speaker: Laelius
sp.p: Atqui, Cato, gratissimum nobis, ut etiam pro Scipione pollicear, feceris, si, quoniam speramus, volumus quidem certe, senes fieri, multo ante a te didicerimus quibus facillime rationibus ingravescentem aetatem ferre possimus.

sp.speaker: Cato
sp.p: Faciam vero, Laeli, praesertim si utrique vestrum, ut dicis, gratum futurum est.

div.head: Symbols Commonly Used in the Text of a Critical Edition
div.p: The symbols in this section have been gleaned from Martin West, Textual Criticism and Editorial Technique (Stuttgart, 1973), 80–81.

For the sake of uniformity, this section follows closely Tom Elliott, Gabriel Bodard, Elli Mylonas, Simona Stoyanova, Charlotte Tupman, Scott Vanderbilt, et al. (2007-2014), EpiDoc Guidelines: Ancient documents in TEI XML (Version 8). Available: http://www.stoa.org/epidoc/gl/latest.

div.head: Abbreviation Fully Expanded
div.p: The LDLT follows the Epidoc guidelines for encoding fully expanded abbreviations :
expan (expansion) contains the full expansion of an abbreviation.
abbr (abbreviation) contains the abbreviated part, i.e. the letters actually on the page.
ex (editorial expansion) contains a sequence of letters added by an editor or transcriber when expanding an abbreviation.
Multiple <abbr> elements within a single <expan> compose a single abbreviation between them. For example, e.g. is one abbreviation for the phrase "exempli gratia."

div.head: Text added by emendation
div.p: An editor supplies text believed to be missing from the original source. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines "Editorial Restoration: Characters Lost But Restored By Modern Editor" )
supplied signifies text believed by the transcriber or editor to be missing.
reason indicates that text has been omitted, but supplied by emendation.

div.head: Undetermined Amount Of Text Lost
div.p: Text has been lost from one or more witnesses. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Characters, Quantity Unknown" )
gap signifies text missing because of damage.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
extent with value "unknown" indicates that an undetermined amount of text has been lost.
unit with value "characters" indicates that an unspecified number of characters (whether single characters or words or larger groups of text) have been lost.

div.head: Known Amount Of Text Lost
div.p: The editor or transcriber knows from context and/or observation how much text has been lost. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Characters, Quantity Known" )
gap signifies text missing.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
quantity indicates the amount of text has been lost.
unit indicates the unit measured in quantity.
Note that each dot represents a missing character.

div.head: Known Number of Lines Lost
div.p: A known quantity of lines has been lost, or is conjectured to have been lost from the text of all witnesses. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Lines, Quantity Known" )
gap signifies that text is missing.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
quantity indicates the number of lines missing.
unit with value "line" indicates the unit measured in quantity.
Note that the brackets and the dashes represent one missing line. The number in quantity will determine the number of instances of that group of characters, one per line.

div.head: Unknown Number of Lines Lost
div.p: An unknown quantity of lines has been lost, or is conjectured to have been lost from the text of all witnesses. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Lines, Quantity Unknown" )
gap signifies that text is missing.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
extent with value "unknown" indicates that nothing more is known about the amount of text that has been lost.
unit with value "line" indicates the unit measured in extent.

div.head: Editorial Deletion
div.p: Text suspected by the editor to be superfluous, but retained in the main text to indicate its traditional attribution to the author. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Superfluous Text" )
surplus signifies text identified by the editor as added by someone other than the original author.

div.head: Crux
div.p: Text deemed by the editor to be irredeemably corrupt. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Ambiguous Characters" )
unclear indicates that the text is readable but not understandable.

div.head: Apparatus Criticus
div.p: This section provides models for handling the different kinds of data that occur in the apparatus criticus.
app (apparatus entry) contains the lemma and readings for a single entry in the apparatus criticus, though it and its contents may be nested inside of another app
lem (lemma) contains a reading judged by the editor to be what the author wrote, or as close as possible. This type of reading constitutes the text printed in the main portion of a critical edition.

rdg (reading) contains some text (or absence of text) witnessed by a manuscript or found in an early printed edition where it is not expressly proposed, but judged by the editor to be unsatisfactory or corrupt for linguistic and/or stylistic reasons. This text is printed in the apparatus criticus.
wit (witness) indicates any manuscript(s) or early printed edition(s) (esp. without an apparatus or commentary; i.e., editiones vetustiores)
source (source) indicates any printed edition(s) or other scholarly work(s) (e.g., article, textual note, commentary) addressing an aspect of the text.
ana (analysis) indicates that a reading belongs to at least one category in the LDLT's taxonomy of readings. More than one value is possible.
witDetail (witness detail) contains information about a particular witness (wit) to a lemma (lem) or reading (rdg).
note (note) contains editorial comments, bibliographical references, or other information pertaining to the apparatus entry.
Need discussion about the order in which information is presented.

div.head: Basic reporting of a variant reading
div.p: A witness or source has a reading that varies from the lemma in some way. For example, if the editor has accepted the text Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet into the main text of the edition, but manuscript A has larem instead of lorem, the variant reading would be reported in a printed edition as follows:
Since the lemma is not typically printed in an apparatus criticus (unless there is a chance for confusion), it is up to the reader to recognize that larem is a variant for lorem.
In this model, an app contains both the lemma and the variant reading, reducing the need for guesswork, at least when looking at the XML code.

The patterns displayed below are designed to handle the various kinds of information conveyed in a typical apparatus criticus, including readings ante correctionem and in rasura, among other paleographical and editorial details.

egXML.p: Lorem larem ipsum dolor sit amet

div.p: If an editor deems it important to indicate that a rdg also appears in a source, the same pattern applies, but source is added after wit:

egXML.p: Lorem larem ipsum dolor sit amet

div.p: If there are multiple variant readings, another rdg should be added for each one.

egXML.p: Lorem larem lurum ipsum dolor sit amet

div.head: Additions
div.p: A witness or source adds text (e.g., in the margin) that an editor deems worthy of notice.
add (addition) contains text that has been added.

place indicates the placed where the text has been added. Possible values:
above: above the line (suprascr. = superscriptum/a)
below: below the line (subscr. = subscriptum/a)
bottom: bottom of the page (ad fin. = ad finem
inline: within the body of the original text (in textu)
inRas: in the space where text has been erased. (in ras. = in rasura)
margin: right, left, or both (in mg. = in margine)
top: at the top of the page (ad init. = ad initium
hand indicates the manuscript hand that added the text. See the section on manuscript hands for more information about encoding that information.
For example, the copyist of manuscript N has the lemma, but a second hand has added a variant reading in the margin.

div.head: Deletions
div.p: A witness or source has deleted some text, and an editor deems it worthy of notice.
del (deletion) contains text that has been deleted.

rend (rendition) indicates the method of deletion. Possible values:
erasure: text has been physically removed from the page or lines have been drawn through it (del. = delevit/deleverunt)
expunction: text has been marked for deletion with dots underneath (exp. = expunxit/expunxerunt)
For example, the copyist of manuscript N has printed the lemma tristique, but a later hand has deleted the letters que.

Note that ana with value "subtractive" is on the app to indicate that the entire entry concerns a reading that takes away something from the lemma. If there are several rdg elements and not all of them are subtractive in nature, ana would be applied to the relevant rdg.

div.head: Omissions
div.p: A witness or source omits some text and the editor deems it important to report the omission.

For example, the witness known as "P" has omitted the word pecus from the following text: securo custode pecus nocturnaque pastor. The traditional apparatus criticus indicates the omission as follows:
In this model, the omission is represented by a "self-closing" rdg:

Note that ana is used with the value "subtractive" to enable querying for this type of data. If there is only one rdg, then ana="subtractive" is attached to app to indicate that the entire entry in the apparatus concerns an omission. If an omission is to be reported among other readings, ana="subtractive" is applied to the rdg that reports the omission:

egXML.l:
securo custode pecus pecore
nocturnaque pastor

div.p: The same model applies to the omission of an entire line of verse, but in that case app (with type="lineOmission") and lem contain the entire line, and the omission is marked by a self-closing rdg:

lem.l: et spument rauco ferventia musta susurro.

div.p: This is displayed in the apparatus criticus as vers. om. κχ

div.head: Lacuna
div.p: A witness is missing a portion of the text.
lacunaStart is a self-closing tag with wit indicating where in a witness the lacuna begins.
lacunaEnd is a self-closing tag with wit indicating where in a witness the lacuna ends.

For example, witness N has a lacuna that begins after the word metus and ends before the word arcu in the following passage: Mauris ut mauris et metus pharetra dictum et risus. Suspendisse ut maximus diam. Suspendisse luctus diam non libero pellentesque, et aliquam ex congue. Suspendisse vitae lacinia urna, nec egestas arcu. Quisque eget.
A traditional apparatus criticus might have the following to indicate the lacuna:

egXML.p:
Mauris ut mauris et metus pharetra
dictum et risus. Suspendisse ut maximus diam. Suspendisse luctus diam non libero pellentesque, et aliquam ex congue. Suspendisse vitae lacinia urna, nec egestas
arcu. Quisque eget.

div.head: Corrections
div.p: A variant reading has been corrected to the value of the lemma, but the editor deems the reading prior to correction worthy of notice.

rdgGrp (reading group) contains the readings before and after correction, but since the emphasis is on the original, uncorrected, reading, type is applied with the value "anteCorr" (i.e., ante correctionem)
varSeq (variant sequence) indicates the order of the readings (e.g., 1 for the first reading, 2 for the correction.
copyOf indicates that the correction is a copy of the lemma. Instead of copying the value of the lemma, we point to it to indicate that they are the same.
For example, manuscript N originally had quaedam for the lemma quidem. The editor wishes to note the reading ante correctionem.

In a traditional critical edition, this would be handled in the apparatus criticus as follows: quaedam N (ante corr. N¹). There is no need to print the result of the correction, since "correction" implies the editor's accepted reading (i.e., lemma).
Note that the lem must have an xml:id to be a target for copyOf
This pattern is the basis for a number of other representations of reading sequences.

div.head: Correction in the Margin
div.p: A manuscript hand has corrected a variant reading to the lemma by writing it in the margin.

For example, manuscript G has iantabimur in the text, but a second hand has added the accepted reading mactabimus in the margin. This would be handled in a traditional apparatus as follows: iantabimur G (corr. G² in mg.).
A self-closing add is used here with place and copyOf to indicate that the marginal reading is identical to the accepted reading.

div.head: Correction of an Omission
div.p: The original copyist has omitted a reading from the text, but another hand (or the original copyist) has supplied the missing text.
For example, manuscript G has omitted the lemma tandem, but the original copyist has supplied it. In a traditional critical edition, that would be represented as follows: tandem] om. G (corr. G¹).
If the corrector has added the reading in the margin or elsewhere (e.g., tandem] om. G (corr. G¹ in mg.), add with place and copyOf can be used:

div.head: Correction by Addition
div.p: A variant reading differs from the lemma by one or more characters, which have been supplied by the original copyist or another hand at a later time.

For example, manuscript N has insidia, which differs from the lemma insidiaby a single letter "s". A later hand has added the missing "s". That might be handled as follows in a traditional apparatus criticus: insidia N (s add. N²).

div.head: Correction by Deletion
div.p: A variant reading differs from the lemma by one or more characters, which have been deleted by the original copyist or another hand at a later time.

For example, manuscript N has the reading cogaudete where the lemma is just gaudete. The original copyist has deleted the letters "co" from the beginning of the word. In a traditional apparatus criticus, that might be printed as follows: cogaudete N (corr. N¹, co exp.).

div.head: One Witness Among Many Has Been Corrected
div.p: A variant reading has several witnesses, but only one of them has been corrected, and the editor believes it is important to make that clear.

For example, manuscripts P Q R S T U V have the variant reading flore where the lemma is Flora. Only manuscript T has been corrected. In a traditional apparatus criticus, that might be handled as follows: flore PQRST (corr. T¹) UV.
Since only one witness has been corrected, rdgGrp with type="anteCorr" cannot contain the reading of all of the manuscripts, so we must use copyOf on both the lemma and the variant reading.

div.head: Mutation
div.p: Sometimes the copyist or a later hand "corrects" a variant reading to another variant reading. Although the motivation may have been to correct, the action results in mutation.
For example, manuscript N has dipicta for lemma descripta, and the original copyist has "corrected" the reading to depicta.
A traditional apparatus criticus might handle that as follows: dipicta N (mut. in depicta N¹).
The same pattern for the ante correctionem scenarios can be used here, with a different value for type ("mutation") on rdgGrp:

div.head: Conjecture
div.p: A conjecture is some portion of text (or absence of text) proposed by some person (ancient or modern) and determined by an editor to be worthy of consideration in establishing the text, but not to be printed in the main text of the edition.
In a traditional critical edition, a conjecture might be noted as follows: rapidoque] rabidoque conj. Baehrens.

Although conjectures are more common in modern editions and other scholarship, they are not unheard of in manuscripts, where a hand has written a reading (e.g., in the margin) that does not resemble any other variant readings and cannot be attributed to a recognizable error. Therefore, conjecture is not limited to those materials identified in source. For this reason, type with value "conjecture" must be used to identify a reading as a conjecture.

In this example, type is attached to app because the entire entry concerns a conjecture. If the conjecture is just one among many readings, type must be used on the individual rdg that contains the conjecture.
If a single scholar has proposed multiple conjectures for a single lemma, rdgGrp with type contains all of the conjectures as individual readings:
That should be displayed as: nullosque sui vel nullosque duics vel nullosque ducum conj. Heins.

div.head: Emendation
div.p: An emendation is a "successful" conjecture. That is, an emendation is some portion of text (or absence of text) expressly proposed by some person through the application of critical judgment, accepted by the editor in place of the transmitted readings, and printed in the main text of an edition. For this reason, only a lemma can be classified as an emendation.
The following example illustrates the difference between an emendation and a conjecture by virtue of the fact that the lem has type="emendation" and rdg has type="conjecture":

div.head: Notes
div.p: An editor wishes to comment on a reading, include bibliographical information, or note something else about the passage in question.

For example, the editor has recorded a variant reading that another scholar has supported in a textual note. That would be handled in a traditional edition as follows: molle sub] molliter Glaeser, def. Jacoby (Wochenschrift für klassische Philologie III, 1886, p. 1290).
We handle this with note with target pointing at the value of xml:id on the lem or rdg in question.

app.note: Jacoby defendit (Wochenschrift für klassische Philologie III, 1886, p. 1290)
